24657369.review:
Book of Demons is an homage and love letter to the Diablo series and old hack&slash games. This is my first ever review and the first ever early access game I bought on steam and it was worth it for this game. You want to know why?

Book of Demons, while still Early Access, is incredibly polished in it's current state. This game just oozes atmosphere. You find yourself in a little town and your goal is to purge the church (and what's under it) from evil. Sounds close to Diablo, right? And that's what's so great about this game. Being an homage it takes the best the Diablo series has to offer and presents it in a whole new package. One of the greatest thing about this game is its graphics and art design. The game is set in a papercrafted world, which has its own unique charme to it.

Your goal is to clear procedually generated dungeons till you reach the utter bottom where an evil awaits you that likes to play with rubber ducks while bathing in fire (game has great humor), get new cards which you can collect and equip, get loot and gold. Book of Demons offers several sub-systems, such as upgrading your looted cards which are your skills you use in the game. These cards can also be charged in between each dungeon. You can also open the so called cauldron for gold, which gives you a prize (or prizes) and either HP or mana. 

While in a dungeon you move your character on predetermined paths by clicking in the direction you want to go. Enemies are also fought by clicking on them and often require different approaches. Sometimes you have to first click away their block before you can attack them, other times you have to stop mages from casting so they don't become a bigger threat than they already are. The game keeps these encounters fresh by introducing new mechanics and enemies all the time. The movement of the character could be improved (don't forget that it's fresh in early access) and the developers are already working on enabling WASD as a movement option.

To keep it short I'm gonna list some positives/negatives:

[b]Thumbs up[/b]

-Graphics and art design
-Oozes atmosphere
-Good Soundtrack and voice work
-Humor
-Variety of enemies
-Almost no bugs and no crashes so far
-Good performance
-Great card collecting and skill system
-3 distinct classes (mage, rogue and warrior) -> only warrior enabled right now though
-Procedually generated dungeons
-Cool boss encounters which keep you on your toes
-Integrated Feedback system
-Absolutely great involvement from the developers concerning the community. Issues and feedback threads are getting noticed almost immediately and are getting individual responses from the developer team. They really want to make a great game (they are almost there).

[b]Thumbs Down[/b]

-Could use a little bit snappier movement (WASD option already in work though!)
-Sometimes frustrating encounters with countless archers and mages shooting at you
-Some balancing issues concerning encounters and dungeon rooms

24650910.review: much fun, reminded me of playing diablo when i was a younger.  if you enjoyed the diablo franchise and want a fresh take on it check this game out.

24646420.review:
I have mixed experiences about this game. Also, please note that this review is from an Early Access version of the game (first release to be specific). I've played Book of Demons for two hours and have experienced a fair amount of the game to write this review. Now this review is very much my opinion, but I will be explaining the positives and negatives with both facts and feeling.

Book of Demons is an ARPG that is ment to be a Paperverse parody of the first Diablo game. It uses a familiar feel of the Diablo franchise (both in looks, gameplay, and story) but makes itself a unique take on the hack-n-slash classic. 

So in Book of Demons you have a hand made up of cards obtained throughout the dungeons you explore. You start out with the capacity for only three cards but can begin to expand to a maxamum of 10 cards in your hand. These cards can be interchanged at any time, allowing for various ways of playing your character. When you die in a dungeon you lose everything in your hand, as well as all of your money; the only way to get your cards and money back is by finding your body in the dungeon and picking up your items. This sounds simple enough but can become quite problematic. 

A big issue with this is that you can easily and quickly become overwhelmed by mobs of enemies that: poison upon death, freeze you in place, can stun you, surround you (which stops you from escaping), and many other things. If you become surrounded, poisoned, frozen and so forth you can very quickly die. The worst offender of them all becomes the stun mechanic which forces you to catch several wandering stars inorder to take any action in the game again, all the while the enemies are killing you... horribly. 

In additon, the movement while in combat is atrocious. When you go to attack an enemy, there are times when it doesnt register right, or you miss click ever so slightly, and begin charging to the enemy horde. Meanwhile, when you try to move away from the enemies, you have to spam click only to be rewarded with the character hesitently moving away from the mobs. Getting your character to backtrack away from enemies is one of the most frustrating things about this game. 

Not to mention everything costs money. Everything. And a LOT of it. First hand expansion slot? 5,000 gold. The second? 10,000. Rune merging, card charging (the ones that require it), card upgrading, culdron of rewards, identifying an unknown item, and more... all cost. Its quite excessive, unnecessarily so. Even for a grindy dungeon crawling hack-n-slash.

Now while I have some grievences I do have things that I love about this game. The art style for one. I absolutely love the pop-up style design of Book of Demons. Then theres the voice acting, which is rich and captivating. The funny nuances and unique beastery, mixed with a wondeful ambeance, really bring this game to life in a spectacular way. Not to mention all the different combinations of cards you can set as your hand, giving you many different ways to play Book of Demons.

So, allow me to simplify this with a pro's and cons list to allow for a more condensed viewing:

Pro's:
*Art
*Music
*Voice Acting
*Random Dungeon Generation
*Conceptulization
*Card System
*Reward System
*Runs Smooth

Con's:
*Stun System
*Overly Brutal at Early Levels
*Just Overly Brutal in General
*Movement While in Combat 
*Death is too Harsh
*Everything is Costly
*Monsteres Swarm You Stopping You From Escaping

These are just a few of the Pro's and Con's, as going into an even further explination would make this review become much longer. In the end, there were so many issues with my dungeon experience, it made progressing impossible. I've played Diablo II and Diablo III for a very long time, and have completed them on the most extreme of difficulties. This, however, made me struggle out of nowhere. 

For the first hour everything was okay with minor challenge as I was learning how to play. During the second hour the difficulty shot to a level that you would expect from the end layers of the game. I wanted this game to be amazing, and during the beginning it was... it was only after the first hour that my fun turned into an unbearable frustration of inpassability. 

If you are a fan of the Diablo franchise, and were expecting it to be like Diablo but with a unique comedic twist, then this game is not for you. If however, you enjoy ARPG hack-n-slash games and do not mind the current issues that may or may not ever be resolved, then please, buy this game and have fun. Maybe oneday I will re-purchase this game, but so long as it remains a game that I cannot complete with all the issues I had encountered then I shall move on to the next thing.

I recomend this game to people who love ARPG's and hack-n-slash game who do not mind the extreme difficulty and wonky mechanics. For anyone else, take some time to watch a lot of videos on it and research if this really is a game you would enjoy. Don't just go for it over the first few glances you see. Just be weary, prospective buyer. I hope other people have a better experience that I had.

24627454.review:
Book of Demons is one of those “could have been” games.  It could have been a great game, but there are so many things that I find so annoying when I play that I have to wonder why they were put in the game in the first place.  These aren't bugs.  This isn't a case of early access working the kinks out of the game.  These are features of the game which serve only to detract from the enjoyment.

One issue I have, and the one that became the most annoying to me, is that whenever your character gets stunned, a circle of stars appear on the screen, and you have to catch them all so that you can end the stun and get back to the game.  It feels like an N64 Mario minigame being randomly activated while I'm playing.  Really, it's hard for me to explain how stupid this is unless you've played the game, and I'm not for a minute suggesting that you do.  Look, imagine that every time you sat down to eat a meal, every so often someone would start waving crap in front of your face and you had to grab  it before you could take another bite.  This is how Book of Demons do.

On it goes, from the ability cards that get deactivated or “tilted” with no notice, to the wandering around to find the piece of gold laying behind a statue somewhere because the level isn't “complete” without it, to the monsters that can attack you from offscreen, well, you get the idea.

I've almost finished Book of Demons, and I'm going to see it through to the end.  It's such a cool idea that I want to like it so much more than I do.  I guess I plan to finish it not because of what it is, but what it could have been.  It could have been a great game.

**edit**  Well, despite saying I was going to finish this game, I ran into another issue that seems to be a major roadblock.  I'm pretty close to the bottom of the dungeon, and monsters are rather numerous.  Three summoners are sitting on the stairs to the previous level.  Every time I try to click on them to fight, I go up the stairs.  All I can do is continuously fight the minons they summon.  This is getting tedious.

8-13-2016 update:  Despite the horrid creatures that lurk within the Book of Demons, I do check back on the game to see if any of the issues I have had are fixed.  By horrid creatures, I don't mean the monsters in the game, I mean the people who play it, but anyway.  I will gladly remove each issue I mentioned as they go away, if they do, but so far it has been the same.  At least by now all of the special needs children who trolled my review and profile have either been blocked by me, or have moved on to more pressing issues such as eating paint chips.  So there's that at least.

4-17-17 update:  Forgot this game existed until the developer commented on this review.  Reinstalled it, and feel pretty much the same as before.  Got stunned and had to catch the stars.  I know they say there is an item that prevents that, but I don't have one, and it's still an annoying mechanic.  So is the transition between rooms, which often wind up with me doing a dance in and out of a room because there are several enemies standing by the door.  I very quickly noticed the same old annoyances from before. You know, this game has been available for sale for long enough to consider this my final revision.  Early access is one thing, but its not early any more.

24620200.review:
Very interesting game and a lovingly-made homage to Diablo 1.

While the game is an ARPG, your character can only move in predefined paths. This takes some getting used to especially since the controls are still a bit clunky and unresponsive (I have almost died several times because my character was going in a direction it wasn't supposed to or it wasn't moving at all despite frantically clicking with the mouse). However, the voice acting, art style, graphics, and deck building mechanics are top notch. A lot of times the game feels less hack and slash and more action-puzzle (like Legend of Zelda) since a wrong move can spell either escape or utter defeat (and believe me, dying in this game really sucks). In this sense, it somehow becomes a rogue-lite.

PROS:
+ Exquisite art style, beautiful sound design, and a thoroughly immersive theme and atmosphere
+ Interesting combat mechanic (sadly marred by clunky mouse controls - hoping it gets fixed in the future)
+ High replay value due to procedurally generated dungeons
+ You feel that this game was made with just so much heart and love for the genre

CONS:
- Clunky/unresponsive movements
- Game difficulty ramps up too quickly for comfort. This is not a game you can just relax with and just hack and slash and kill monsters with like Diablo or Torchlight
- Dying equates to significant loss in cauldron rewards (which is a big deal as cauldron rewards award life or mana points)
- Some bugs (like my character disappearing all of sudden) but hopefully this gets ironed out when the game leaves early access


TLDR: Get it. Game is worth it even in Early Access.

24609571.review:
[quote=Изготовитель луков в Солитьюде. «The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim»]- Мне нужны стрелы, которые могут сразить дракона.
- Ну, конечно. А лук, который стреляет радугой, тебе не нужен? Или колчан, который разливает пиво?[/quote]

[b]Book of Demons[/b] - ролевое приключение от польской студии [b]Thing Trunk[/b], которое входит в программу [b]Return 2 Games[/b]! Сама концепция программы достаточна любопытна и заинтересует многих игроков, суть ее заключается в том, чтобы выпустить семь игр в различных жанрах, возрождающих ощущения от известных в 90-е годы проектов. [b]Book of Demons[/b] - это первый «том» этой серии, отдающий дань уважения [b]RPG[/b] и [b]Hack & Slash[/b]. Уже анонсирован второй проект, который будет посвящен жанру [b]Sandbox[/b].

Сюжет игры достаточно прост и незатейлив. Герой, вернувшийся после длительных приключений, видит запустение и упадок в родных краях. Оказывается, некоторое время назад, странные события начали происходить под старым собором, сперва пропал местный священник, а потом в округе стали появляться загадочные существа похожие на людей. Паника начала возрастать, более отчаянные и смелые отправились в собор, но их никто больше не видел, трусливые нашли спасение в бегстве, а некоторые и вовсе решили не обращать внимания на происходящее и стали вести затворнический образ жизни. Теперь вся надежда на вас!

Помогать герою будет подруга детства, которая умеет создавать магические эликсиры, мудрый старейшина, знающий многое о местных монстрах и способный распознавать карты, гадалка, обученная некоторым таинствам, благодаря которым может работать с магическими картами, и целительница, готовая залечить раны героя или же спасти его душу от забвения!

Визуальный стиль [b]Book of Demons[/b] необычен, и напоминает бумажные аппликации, вырезанные из бумаги. Смотрится это стильно, и очень органично дополняет атмосферу игры, которая разбавлена изрядной толикой юмора! Чего только стоят колкие высказывания жителей деревни в отношении друг друга!

Хочется отметить интересный механизм [b]Flexiscope[/b], который позволяет игроку самостоятельно определять длительность сессии! Чем длиннее игровая партия, тем выше награда. Подземелья генерируются случайным образом и представляют из себя небольшие лабиринты, в которых герой двигается по заранее вытоптанным дорожкам. Наполнение подземелий классическое, помимо монстров можно найти фонтаны, восстанавливающие здоровье и ману героя, различные типы сундуков, от обычных до охраняемых, и специальные локации, на которых можно на постоянной основе поднять параметры героя. 

Заявлено более 60 типов врагов, которые разделены на классы. Например, обычный скелет может иметь около 15 вариаций, от обычного до улучшенного с магическими способностями, к тому же можно встретить противников, усиленных элементными атаками, которые запросто могут обездвижить или сжечь героя. К некоторым врагам нужно найти свой подход, к примеру, боссы могут иметь несколько жизней, сильные маги привязывают свою защиту к вызываемым существам, и пока не убьешь последних, самого мага недостать, другие после пропущенного удара временно становятся неуязвимыми и т.д. Представьте сражение в маленькой комнате, набитой различными типами существ! 

[i]Из-за ограничений на количество символов (не влезло около 3000 знаков), полную версию обзора вы можете прочитать  [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SpecialGamesClub#announcements/detail/595984062704822847][u]здесь[/u][/url].[/i]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1136451407
Praticamente uma versão "Newgen" de Diablo 1, voltada para um público mais casual, pois ao contrário dos ARPGs convencionais, o loot é limitado, portanto, nada de grind.

A jogabilidade base foi extremamente alterada, simplificando muito a movimentação, e adicionando um punhado de mecânicas simples, porém únicas e divertidas, que ao todo, tornam o jogo bem interativo.

Mesmo estando em acesso antecipado, está extremamente polido. A parte visual é simples em teoria, usando o estilo papercraft para tudo, sem animações, mas na prática, é muito bela e agradável, com efeitos até mesmo em toda interface.

Quem assim como eu foi muito fã de Diablo 1 e não possui a mesma paciência ou tempo para ficar indo atrás de loot, vai curtir muito!

24596212.review:
I have played many games through the years, triple a titles and as of recently indie titles alot of indie titles. 

Many of them have been good, and then like in most cases there have also been bad games, now the question is, is book of demons one of the good or the bad?

None of the above, it's not bad and it's not good it is absolutly AMAZING! This game is Diablo 1 only difference being, it is paper craft and you follow a linear path and ofc your attacks are "ranged" as in you can attack what is in your light radius and the smith or in general the weapons have been replaced with cards.

As you progress you collect more cards and you can unlock more card slots, more cards equipped = Stronger character with more benefits, but you really have to chose wisely. 

The graphics are absolutly stunning if you like the papercraftish theme ofc, and the narration and voice acting is top notch nothing negative to say about it.

Overall this game has to be one of the best indie games I have played this year, and I am looking forward to more releases from these guys. 

Would I recommend this game? Well I pressed yes, but there should be an option called MUST BUY! If you don't buy you are missing out on an absolutly amazing game.

24595266.review:
Edit: After over 20h spent in-game since its launch, I'm still enjoying it a lot. Trying to get my cards to max level and running for achievements. Money well-spent.

If you think whether you should buy this game or not, stop it right now. Because if you're into Hack'n'Slash, dungeon crawlers, and action RPGs, Book of Demons IS the perfect game for you. 

I got excited when I first saw the screenshots drifting somewhere on the Internet, but at the same time I knew it might be "just another clone." However, after I met the developers at a Polish event and played the Pre-Beta Demo, I knew I had to have this game on Day 1. 

I love the paper craft art design, music and voice acting. I also enjoy the fact that instead of regular items you have these CARDS that you can switch and upgrade whenever you want. Because of this, the possibilities to play your character are endless. Well, maybe not "infinite," but you can try multiple builds with the same character. For instance: AoE build, Single-attack Glass Cannon or Bomb thrower - just to name a few.  

Learning curve is great too. Our class is well-balanced even if you sometimes have problems defeating certain levels. After those 8 hours I know, that if I can't defeat an enemy I just have to switch build and use all the cards I have to progress in the storyline. 

Overall, a must-have for any fan of the genre. But if you've never played aRPGs and Dungeon Crawlers, Book of Demons might help you change your mind. Good luck!

24592816.review:
Well since I've played 1.9h I want to share my thoughts with you guys (sorry for my english gramar I'm spanish). 

The game is nice, there are a few things that can be improved but works really fine. It's a mix of Diablo, Paper Mario and point and click. I just played with the mouse (keyboard is just for a few keys).

[h1] POSITIVE[/h1]
+ You can send a feedback everytime you want to the devs, aslo sometimes after close the game you can make an optional survey to share your thoughs with the devs.

+ Toons of skills, spells, monsters.

You can choose your dificulty dungeon based on :

+ The estimated time you will play (this is great if you run out of time)
+ The more time you choose to play the dungeon (you can leave to town without any penalty) the more rewards and loot you get.

[h1] NEGATIVE [/h1]

- There are some bugs with the mouse, sometimes you can't pick any loot.
- Cannot mute the Sage when he is talking about the bestiary.
- Cannot pause the game while in tutorial, the game still playing as the enemies can hit you while you are reading it.
- Hard to pick the cards (when you have toons of them) in combat, you can die if you don't have a faster mouse.

Do I recommend this game? YES 

13€ - 14$ well expended!!!

9/10

Thanks for reading!!!

24589022.review:
So, looking at the game on steam store page, I debated for about 2 hours to buy this. I love hack and slash/ diablo like games. The loot grind calls my name. But the artistic direction threw me off of an impulse buy. But I am so glad that I picked it up.

So, this game is the first in a 7 game series to pay homeage to old pc gems. This is obviously based on the first Diablo game. How did they do?  Fantastic. This game is just great. I dont feel like i am playing diablo at all, but I can see the inspiration. That is what makes me so happy. If I want to play Diablo, I'll just go do that. But this game is unique in its art direction and game mechanics in a great way.

So how was my experience? Well, I thought I woud write my review after an hour-hour and a half. At around the point where people debate refunds from steam. So what am I thinking? Well, after about 20 minutes in the game, a bit of world building an a small dungeon later, I encounter one of this games best features, IMO. 

So, I am a husband and a PhD student working on his disertation in post-quantum crypto. So my gaming hobby doesnt get all the time i wish it did. But, sometimes I ahve 15 minutes of nothing and would liek to hop into a game. I cant try to get back into a game like witcher3 where I would barely get into a side quest. Not enough time for a round of my moba or mmo of the month. Yet, Book of Demons has a beautiful solution. So, when you go to enther the dungeon, after your first one, you encounter a slider bar, which changes the lenth of dungeon you can enter, with a time estimator. This time estimator will learn based on your previous dungeon runs to become more accurate. This feature alone made me go to the main website and purchase the founders bundle for all 7 games. (I dont expect this feature in all 7, but this game just made me too happy to not want to throw my money at R2G)

So, now when I have 10 minutes or an hour, I can choose a dungeon of appropiate length, and have a blast with the card based ability/armor/loot system. I know there is a good amount of humor and movie/game references in this game, which I look forward to finding. Also, for achievement hunters, this game has 150 i believe? I read that in a forum post, so dont quote me on that. 

Anyway, sorry for the long review, but just a fantastic job Return 2 Games. I look forward to the final product of Book of Demons and the other 6 installments of your series. I gladly throw my money at you for your hard work and will continue to be a happy customer.

24587638.review:
(バグが修正され進行できるようになったので一通りゲームをクリアした後、レビューの一部修正しました。)

カードを集めてそれの組み合わせで自分のビルドを組みダンジョンを攻略していき、カードを強化して更に奥へ……というハクスラチックなゲーム。
しかしながら、売りの一つであろうそのカードシステムが現状では魅力的に機能しているとは言いがたい。最大10種類までカードを選択できるが、必須ではないだろうかと思われるカードが多すぎて、とてもではないがカードの組み合わせについて自由度が高いとはいえない。

敵がスペル詠唱を始めるとその敵は無敵状態になる。スペルの詠唱を中断させるためにスペル詠唱マークにカーソルを合わせてクリックを長押ししなければならないのだが、大量の敵が沸くと次から次へと詠唱を始めていくのでどうしようもなくなる。
一部の敵に付与されているシールドはシールドのアイコン部分を長押しすることで破壊しなければ敵にダメージを与えることはできない。
一定ダメージを与えると一定時間無敵状態になる敵も存在する。
スタンした場合、画面に飛び回る星のアイコンを複数個クリックして解除する必要がある。
連続でスタンする状況に陥ると、当然スタン解除の画面が連続して続く。
このあたりの要素が特にテンポを悪くしており、非常に退屈だと感じる場面が多々あった。

クリア後にフリープレイモードが存在しており、それを利用すればゲームのやりこみを深めることも可能だ。
クリア後にゲームに関するアンケートがあるので、その内容が今後良い方向に反映されていくことに期待したい。

バグとゲーム自体のテンポの悪さやバランスが改善されれば、それなりに楽しめるゲームになるのかもしれないが、現状ではとてもオススメのゲームとしては紹介できない出来だ。
このゲームはあくまでハクスラ「チック」であり、実際にプレイしている感覚としてはハクスラとクリッカーゲームの間という感覚が最も近いのではないだろうか。

24584126.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iMz_-_TnqEQ
Na pierwszy rzut oka może się wydawać, że Polacy inspirowali się Diablo trochę zbyt mocno – fabuła Book of Demons jest w zasadzie taka sama jak w dziele Blizzarda, podobna jest także konstrukcja świata, NPC-e czy przeciwnicy. Ale wrażenie to znika, gdy tylko przebrniemy przez kilka pierwszych poziomów. Okazuje się, że twórcy wrzucili do gry tyle oryginalnych rozwiązań i pomysłów, że spokojnie dałoby się nimi obdarować ze trzy tego typu produkcje. Z ubogiego krewnego już po chwili robi się bogaty wujek z Ameryki, który obsypuje nas prezentami.

Zamiast ograniczać się do ogranego klikania stworków i łykania potionów, Thing Trunk serwuje solidną porcję kombinowania, masę nietypowych reguł i konieczność skoncentrowania się na wszystkim, co pojawia się na ekranie. Zamiast swobody eksploracji – ograniczenia, które jednak nie tylko nie zmniejszają frajdy płynącej z rozgrywki, ale wręcz ją potęgują. A do tego wszechobecną wygodę i otwartość na każdy typ gracza. Nieważne czy jesteś casualem, czy hardkorowcem, czy masz na zabawę tylko 15 minut, czy cały weekend – Book of Demons próbuje się do ciebie dostosować i doskonale ten czas wypełnić.

I choć pod względem mechaniki gra diametralnie różni się od Diablo, to pod względem dostarczanych emocji jest bardzo podobna. To niezwykle trudny do uzyskania rezultat. A wygląda na to, że się udało. Pierwsza z siedmiu planowanych podróży sentymentalnych ma spore szanse zakończyć się nadspodziewanie dobrze.

Right off the bat, I would highly recommend this game. As a new person to this type of hash and slash adventure game (featuring deck building), I can say I really enjoyed it. As it stands it is almost fully complete already and the campaign is fully playable. I made a pros and cons list below:

Pro:

- Dungeons (campaign) are really fun to play though and have adjustable lengths you can set

- Loot is rewarding and fun to obtain

Cons:

- Lots of dialogue (if you don't like that)

Overall: 9/10 - Very high potential

24581466.review:
Return 2 Games 是一个游戏系列，由7个游戏组成，旨在从旧时代经典游戏中提取元素并创造出易于上手的新作品。对于游戏他们的定位是 "midcore"，这似乎是近几年移动平台兴起后冒出的一个概念，大概就是介于休闲与硬核之间，即可以轻松上手又具备深度的游戏体验。

Book of Demons 是这个系列的首部作品，它把卡牌构筑系统融合进了暗黑类型的游戏之中。不过如果你是喜欢传统的暗黑类型游戏，我建议你还是考虑考虑再掏钱，因为这根本是两种游戏...

首先这个卡牌构筑其实就是个和大多数手游类似的道具卡片化，并没有复杂的机制系统，而且卡片总数量并不算多，所以你想要自由丰富的 Build 和检测自己血统的 Loot 这游戏都很难满足你。

再来说操作，它的操作真的很简单，但是有点简单过头了。除了使用卡片需要按数字键以外，它的全部操作几乎都是靠鼠标完成，点击一个方向他就会沿着路一直移动直到下个路口自动停止，如果你想中途停止移动就需要在人物背后点击一下或者按下Shift键，角色可以自动攻击身边的敌人，不过通过鼠标点击敌人的攻击速度会更快。除此之外还有一些战斗机制也都是通过鼠标来完成的，比如点碎敌人身上的护甲，还有点击法师头顶的图标来打断施法。

虽然这些操作确实很简单，但并不太方便，这给我的感觉像是以触屏的操作体验来设计的，硬般到PC上来显得不那么合适，如果要进行快速准确的点击在某一位置这样的操作，我感觉鼠标是比不上触屏的，这也是这游戏最大的难点，点的准才能快速解决敌人，点的准才能减少误操作从而少受伤害。不过在接受到相关反馈后，开发者应该也在考虑修改方案。

然后美术，这游戏有着独特的立体书式的纸制品风格。人物都是些纸片，基本没什么角色动作，虽然这方式有些讨巧，不过至少人家纸片做得还算精致。

总的来说这游戏看起来有些尴尬，它像是个做在PC上的移动端游戏...也能看得出它吸取了一些移动端游戏成功元素（不是在讽刺），不过个人感觉虽然打发时间来玩玩还不错，但是也说不上特别好玩。 感觉开发者是被自己弄得这个 midcore 受众定位给限制住了。

还有现在测试版本，角色只有一个战士可选，还有两个要之后版本解锁。这个系列的后续作品会以 DLC的形式发售，后续作品类型不同但好像是会保持美术风格以及卡片系统，如果真喜欢这个系列，他们官网现在可以买到系列整包，不过后面的还没做出来，而且价格会比单买首周折扣的国区价格贵上一些。

The game is about Pain Train bringing real pain to demons from hell. Cho-cho! 

-----------------------------------------------------
Game is a fresh indie look on classic Diablo. Image pen-and-paper variation with cards, figures made of paper, original atmosphere and new intresting mechanics that I've never seen before.

24580605.review:
Wow! Just wow!
This game is so good, I had to write my first ever review about it^^

On first sight, the rather unusual papercut aesthetic looks a bit weird and, together with the you-can-only-move-along-a-fixed-path-mechanic, might give the impression of a silly game with rather light mechanisms.
But thats so not the case. The graphics are spot on and convey just the right mood and atmosphere. Its very much like Diablo in that regard, just a tiny bit more funny.
Contrary to that, the mechanics couldn't be more different. Although still a hack'n'slash dungeon crawler, the way to go about your business is very different and refreshingly new. 
Just to name a few:
-inside a dungeon you can only move along a fixed path from junction to junction (although the levels a randomly generated).
-shielded enemies have an actual shield icon somewhere near them, that you have to destroy first before you can damage them.
-gold and health pickups are gathered automatically once you hover your mouse over them.
-random(?) boss monsters have various stages where they use different skills.
-skills from regular monsters (like teleporting or summoning minions) can be cancelled by clicking on them.

Granted, those things make the game sound like some mobile clicker game, but it is not! Its difficult to explain, but as soon as everything is in motion, the game plays very smooth and tactically challenging while still being fast and (once you got used to the unusual ways of controlling) easy at the same time.

About the card mechanics... Don't assume, there is a card game mechanic here. Its just that skills/spells/items are represented as cards. They are equipped on a shared skillbar and can either be passive, activatable for mana or activatable for a specific amount of times before they need to be recharged.

I know I haven't covered all aspects of the game, like the wonderful random dungeon generation with a "learning" time prediction to make the game last exactly as long as you want it to.

This game offeres many new mechanics that at the same time tie in very well to the gameplay we are used to from previous dungeon crawlers. Granted, I've just played one of the three characters for about 90 minutes, but at this point the game feels very polished and I can't wait to see what the devs have up their sleeves for the coming months.

If you like dungeon crawl hack'n'slays - buy it!
If you are interested in cool new mechanics - buy it!

24579671.review:
When I have first seen the game on images, I didn't think much of it. It looked weird, yet I gave it a shot and after starting it up the first time, I played for several hours, untill that game started crashing on one level and I couldn't proceed (played before it was released, didn't encounter any crashes as of today). And I was crushed that I can't continue on, I've been enjoying my time with this title a lot! This day marks the release so I jumped right on it and finished the main story.

If you are seeing this title for the first time, let me tell you why it's worth your time.
This is a hack & slash done right, there's a big enemy pool the game is drawing from and you're seeing something new all the time from basic skeletons and zombies to crazy mages that will fill the screen with spawned enemies and then, if you escape, teleport all of them right on top of you again. You gain loot in the form of money, consumables and most importantly, relics and runes to upgrade these relics in the form of cards. You essentially create your deck of cards that your character will equip and that defines your build. There are 32 cards available for the knight character and you can equip up to 10 of them at a time. You can freely switch your cards even when curently in a dungeon.

At this stage of early access you only have the knight available, your character is stuck in a created path that you can't divert from, yet anemies occupy the whole place. No worries, it works well (although I had to get used to the auto-walk mechanic, where you click in a direction you want to go and your character walks untill he bumps into a cross-road, an enemy or you click behind him) and you can attack in all directions with a surprising ammount of range for a melee character, it feels like you have a bow equiped but honestly with the ammount of enemies you have to deal with in later levels, this only makes sense as you'd get swarmed and killed in no time without this range.

Admitedly, the game felt rather easy, I have yet to die a single time and I have finished the story and done a little of free-play, the first two levels were hardly a challange but once I got into hell it started to be a bit more interesting, there I got to finally see my character's ability when his HP reaches 0 (you gain some HP back and push enemies back, sort of a second-wind mechanic). The difficulty spike in the final area is pretty big and it felt like I jumped over a step before that. Once you enter free-play, enemies do much more damage, feels like a new game +, you keep all your loot and upgrades, but you can replay previous levels and unlock more difficulties for free-play, I can see how the high difficulties will be a big challange.

Bosses are well done, outside of the 3 main bosses, the random ones you encounter in dungeons have various phases that you have to beat in order to kill it. Sometimes you have to stand nearby the boss, sometimes you have to kill his summoned enemies and sometimes you just have to go trigger happy on him , I always feel excited when a boss pops-up and it's a shame they don't seem to appear as often in free-play (from what I can tell you get one at the end of the final dungeon in a level where as in the main mode you can sometimes encounter as many as 3 in a single dungeon). I believe they are randomly generated so sometimes you get a really weak one and sometimes you just wish it would die already. The main trio felt unique, I am going to spoil the first one where you have to destroy many pots to find a key but the pots are trapped with explosives, enemies and really no loot outside of junk, you can get a chain-reaction going there pretty easily as some pots spawn more pots with random properities so if you failed to kill that bomb that explodes into 3 more boms and these explode into 9 more bombs and so on, there's suddenly a swarm of enemies going after you. And that's the first main boss, or at least a path to it, good stuff. I felt that the final boss could have been more unique tho, it felt anticlimactic compared to the other two.

Overall I've had a great time and will most likely be returning to this game from time to time. Give it a shot if you're after a new hack & slash game, this one won't dissapoint you.

39413957.review:
Even though in the survey I checked the "buy the EA game when it's on sale" option, decided to buy it at full price, just to support the developers and also I see it as an investment in this whole Return 2 Games project. 

The game is good by the way. Does it worth 20 bucks? I can't tell yet, but it is definitely a game worth checking out. I suggest to download the demo version (big up for the devs for it, really a missing feature nowadays, I hate buying games without trying them first) and then decide if it's for you or not. 

The game starts off pretty easy and straightforward but gets more and more strategic and somewhat deep later. Despite the mobile game-like gameplay and looks, there is a well thought, complex system down beneath it's surface. 

I'm yet to finish this game but certainly will do. There are 3 "real" bosses in this game as far as I can tell, so it's not the longest game ever created, and I don't know how much of a replay ability the game offers at the moment. 

But it's a nostalgic ride to your childhood gaming memories and as a modern age Diablo remake/parody, it delivers what promises: a well polished, fun and challenging nostalgic game with clever tweaks on the combat system and easter eggs, jokes and whatnots in the storyline. 

Tbh I enjoyed this more than Diablo III at times. I love the fact that dying is a risk, and it's not without consequences. It's not a mindless beat 'em but, but rather a decent ARPG, which respects your time - and I respect the devs for that.

39162453.review:
This game is very enjoyable. 
I would have to say it is a simplified Diablo & POE game. 
The story is a lot like D II. 
The classes each play uniquely, and I would recommend this for all ages. Unlike Diablo or even POE I felt as if the theme didn't ever go above a G rating. I would recommended this as a starting game for sure for children to get into ARPG. The art work is great, the game play is solid, and I beat the game with around 19 hours in, but in reality it probably was closer to 12-14's if that.  I'll probably beat the game with all the classes then who knows from there what I'll do. P.S. do the "hardcore" mode it's a lot better, you just can't die but it adds a bit more fun and risk.

The game recognizes dungeon sizes & the average amount of play time to beat the dungeons this is a great feature. This allows for you to get an idea of how long you can play, just in case your life is very busy/hectic. The difficulty isn't that hard when it's set to normal, the builds are each unique. 

I would watch a youtube play through. If you are looking for a fun ARPG this game is it, but it may be too tame for some. The developers do really care about their game & you honestly can tell they take pride in what they make.

I also forgot to mention the music is great in this game.

39152102.review:
Przyjemny, ale dość prosty (tj. nieskomplikowany) hack'n'slash, który mocno inspiruje się pierwszym Diablo. Wciąga jak każda z tego gatunku i syndrom jeszcze jednej rozgrywki występuje do samego końca. Mi osobiście styl graficzny bardzo się podobał, dostosowywanie czasu rozgrywki, ułatwienia jak licznik niezebranych przedmiotów na planszy czy zaznaczanie odwiedzonych ścieżek postrzegam bardzo na plus. System kart jest ciekawą nowością i zbieranie kart daje tyle samo radochy co polowanie na legendarne bronie w innych tego typu grach, chociaż już po 5-6h można powiedzieć, że widziało się wszystkie karty i jedyne co czeka nas później, to magiczne wersje tych samych skilli. Przeszedłem w ciągu kilku dni i nie żałuję, na pewno wrócę też jeszcze za jakiś czas by odkryć pozostałe dwie klasy.

Niestety nie jest pozbawiona wad. Jedną z nich uważam za chodzenie po szynach. Rozumiem, że autorzy taki mieli zamiar i niejako wokół tego budowali tą grę, stąd np. wojownik potrafi na dobrą sprawę atakować na odległość. Niestety jednak o ile na początku wydaje się to być w porządku, tak później staje się wyraźnym ograniczeniem i frustruje. Przeciwnicy na dobrą sprawę nie różnią się wcale od tych z klasycznych h'n's-ów, a my mamy mocno ograniczone pole manewru. Za często kończy się na tym, że stoimy zblokowani od przodu i od tyłu przez mocne mobki, a zza ekranu prują do nas jednostki nakładając na nas każdy możliwy status. Albo przetankujemy ten moment i uda nam się mob po mobku z tego wydostać, albo zginiemy nie mając za bardzo możliwości rozwązania tej sytuacji.
Sterowanie jest też takie sobie. Nigdy nie miałem z tym problemu w tych grach a Book of Demons jakimś cudem potrafił to skomplikować i sprawić, że nie raz, nie dwa postać robiła coś innego niż ja chciałem, by zrobiła.

Ogólnie to polecam, ale z rezerwą. Jest tam gdzieś w głębi rozgrywki nieoszlifowany diament i gra nawet w obecnym stanie jest przyjemna, ma też jednak sporo frustrujących przypadłości i jest mniej skomplikowana od standardowego h'n's jak Torchlight, Path of Exile czy Grim Dawn. Dla jednych będzie to zaletą, dla innych wadą.

39139226.review:
I initially had no interest in Book of Demons. "Playing cards" was an instant turn off and upon watching videos of it in action, the character bouncing along on a set track like a game piece did nothing for me.

 But someone recommended checking it out on a forum. Their description didn't sound half bad, and upon learning that the cards are your weapons and spells (you don't lose them upon using them) I became more interested. Then I found out it's a homage to the original Diablo and these developers are looking to do more of these nods to '90s classics, and I wanted to show some support. I checked out the demo and had a great time. The game respects your time, so it can set up an adventure for you whether you have fifteen minutes to play or forty five. Gameplay is sort of the "clicky" Diablo style but enemies need to be dealt with in different manners, making combat a little more interesting. I've been very happy with Book of Demons thus far and recommend it to any Diablo fan who's looking for a more laid back ARPG.

Pros:
- Mechanically Solid
- Challenging, but not punishing
- Easy to pick up and play
- Able to easily manage time played (EX. Start a mission when you only have 5 mins, 10 mins, 20 mins. You can play when and how you want easily)
- Good Humor
- Great upgrade/progression system
- Constant updates and bug fixes

Cons are more difficult, as many of the above Pro's can be cons, but I kinda hate to say so as they are also what make the game great, so take these with a grain of salt, as its a great game.
- The humor is good but also sometime references can be stale and overbearing
- Because its so simple and easy to play it can lack some depth
- Lacks a bit of its own storyline as if you have played Diablo (The original), you have played book of demons.

Again Great game, Highly recommend it. EXPECIALLY if you loved the orginal Diablo.

39481297.review:
¡Recomendadísimo comprarlo, aunque sea en Acceso Anticipado! Es de esos proyectos que valen cada céntimo apostar por ellos, a la espera de una traducción a nuestro idioma. Los nostálgicos de los 90 y concretamente de Diablo 1 están de enhorabuena!

Book of Demons, la primera entrega de Return 2 Games, una nueva saga de juegos de corte retro e inspirados en grandes clásicos de ordenador. En esta ocasión, la similitud es más que evidente con el videojuego Diablo, creado por Blizzard Entertainment en 1996.
Se trata por tanto, de un RPG de acción de vista isométrica y con toques de Hack & Slash, pero con una estética un tanto peculiar. Todo lo que vemos en pantalla representa estar hecho de papel, dando un aspecto antiguo a juego de rol de tablero y libro de recortables.
La historia de Book of Demons es la típica lucha del Bien contra el Mal, sobre salvar al mundo de la destrucción total. Tendremos que enfrentarnos a los ejércitos de la oscuridad bajo la Antigua Catedral, en las mazmorras, donde encontraremos de todo tipo de aterradores monstruos y demonios, hasta llegar a lo más profundo de la tierra. ¡Salva al flotante mundo-libro de Versopapel, un universo de papiro que será una de las señas de identidad de la serie de juegos de Return 2 Games!
Como veréis el juego expone los mismos elementos que el juego referenciado, Diablo, pero simplificándolo todavía más hasta parodiarlo incluso con toques humorísticos y más desenfadados.

Os dejo los primeros minutos de partida, para quien le interese verlo en movimiento:
https://youtu.be/F4DO4kcjsfc

"Nostalgia sin desilusiones ni frustraciones y enorme inversión de tiempo: ese es el ambicioso objetivo de Book of Demons, a la vez una parodia y un tributo al Diablo original, realizado en adorables papeles recortables." 
Rock Paper Shotgun

"El objetivo de Book of Demons es fusionar la estrategia y la profundidad de Diablo con el estilo y el encanto de Paper Mario, mediante el uso de un sistema único de movimiento y combate, mecanismos del RPG de acción más accesibles y una dosis justa de humor entrelazada con su tema oscuro. " 
Game Informer

" Book of Demons está destinado a atraer a los recién llegados al género, así como a los fanáticos de los RPG de acción desde hace mucho tiempo que han estado anhelando un tipo diferente de Dungeon Crawler". 
GameSpot

39539277.review:
TL:DR - If you enjoy Diablo then this is well worth the price, even at Early Access

Early Access? -- Devs have an ambitious long term goal and support your faith by rolling out regular updates, keeping the fans informed, and consistenly improving the game. Currently (Jan 2018) the full game is playable and very polished. BoD is showing no signs of being an abandoned cash grab as some Early Access games seem to end up (Looking at YOU, Godus devs!).

Clone of Diablo? -- YES! Take all the great things about Diablo (hack-n-slash, dungeon crawling. multiple classes) and strip away the more cumbersome aspects (inventory managemant, large never ending areas) and you have a core game that has become an industry classic.

Instead of inventory theres a card mechanic. You find, collect, equip, and even upgrade various cards to grant certain abilities, spells, or items. When attacked by spiders my Rogue fav tactic is to cast my 'Fear' spell, making mobs run from me, then activate my fire arrows to burn them all to ashes. No worries however, my mana rechage amulet makes sure I'll be ready again soon for the next wave around the corner. 

BoD provides the basic core Diablo experiance in a simpler format. This game is VERY easy to simply pickup and play at any time, at any level, for as long as you choose.

As long as i choose? -- The Flexiscope concept is genius! Each 'game' length is adjusted by you! Pick how long you want to play, a short game for 15 mins or a big game for 45 minutes, it's up to YOU! The game studies past performance and can estimate how long the amount of levels you've picked will take to play. At first it was a bit inaccuate, but now after 25+ hours of gameplay the system fairly accuarately can predict the time needed for the size of the game I pick. Its all adjustible whenever i start a new 'game' or more accuately a 'round'. A HUGE gameplay conveinence that I'd LOVE to see more games adopt.

What's the mood? -- A fun and almost whimsical papercraft visual presentation imeadiately cuts some of the 'heavyweight' tones of the Diablo storyline, letting you know this game isnt too serious, and yet detailed enough to feel substantial. This isnt a completely causal game. It is very polished, wonderfully voiced acted, excellent mood setting score, and even a bit humerous as well.

40983226.review:
I completed the game with Warrior in 12 hours. It felt... alright, I guess. But definitely not fun.
In short: BoD is a failed attempt to do mobile-ready Diablo clone.
I wonder if it is possible to do good mobile-ready Diablo-clone.

Things I liked:
+ art style, unique and well-executed
+ bestiary, it is quite big and diverse
+ hordes of monsters later in the game
+ Flexiscope system, it allows you to choose size of randomly generated level
+ in-game clock, ballsy move from developer - thumbs up
+ good perfomance, no crashes

Things I disliked:
- everything is a card: skills, spells, equipment, potions... It feels like there is no loot
- Cauldron: you have to pay to get the better half of collected prizes
- character cann't step away from narrow path, while monsters have no such restriction, ARPG on rails, is not an ARPG at all
- no map of level
- too mobile-aware.

40979697.review:
[b] Ранний доступ, который мы заслужили - <<Book of Demons>> [/b]

[h1] И тьма поглотит весь свет… - <<Book of Demons>> [/h1]
<<Book of Demons>> - инди-игра из раннего доступа Steam, представитель жанра ARPG, мрачная и красивая сказка, успешно объединившая в себе интересные механики. Игра позволяет ощутить себя героем, которому предстоит спасти жителей небольшого городка от зла, пробудившегося в подземельях местного собора. Вы будто попадаете в <<Сонную лощину>> Тима Бертона, только вместо всадника без головы тут, в лучших традициях традициях <<Diablo>>, абсолютное зло - Дьявол. Он, кстати, ниже.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338551155

[h1] Классы на выбор и <<прокачка>> [/h1]
Игра предлагает вам выбрать один из трех классов: воин, разбойник и волшебник. На первый взгляд - ничего особенного, классика. Однако <<прокачивать>> своего героя нужно не по привычному дереву умений, а с помощью карт, которые выпадают случайно. У каждого класса эти карты, соответственно, свои. Чтобы повысить эффективность в бою, улучшать нужно тоже эти самые карты, только уже с помощью особых рунных карт. Стоит сказать, что общепринятая в жанре концепция прокачки от карточной механики меняется не сильно, однако часть азарта и интерактивности это все-таки приносит.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338640512

[h1] Персонажи и городок [/h1]
Все взаимодействия с картами нужно проводить с помощью жителей городка. У старого волшебника, например, открывать новые, а у загадочной колдуньи, которую, кстати, волшебник недолюбливает, можно карты улучшить. Истории персонажей, которые раскрываются по ходу сюжета, действительно интересны. Созданной обстановке можно только поаплодировать - завораживает. Читать диалоги интересно, а узнавать о других героях большее хочется снова и снова. Городок уютен, поэтому после зачистки очередного подземелья туда возвращаешься словно в родной дом.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338551375

[h1] Графическое оформление [/h1]
Игра выполнена в картонном стиле, что выглядит достаточно свежо. Со вкусом сделанные текстуры окружения и персонажей порадуют глаза любителей инди-проектов. Простое оформление придется очень кстати обладателям <<игровых ноутбуков>> или слабых ПК: для 2018 года игра совершенно нетребовательна, а картинку предоставляет очень приятную. Однако отмечу, что любителям графики следующего поколения игра может не понравится с первых секунд, так как выглядит она слишком лаконично. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338552495

[h1] Геймплей [/h1]
Игроку предстоит уничтожать боссов, зачищать одно подземелье за другим, приближаясь к Дьяволу. А вот и еще одна интересная механика: передвигаться можно только в четырех направлениях, это при том, что каждый уровень генерируется случайно, а вместе с ним - дорожки, по которым предлагают ходить. С дорожек этих сойти ваш персонаж не может. Монстры, соответственно, обычно располагаются в огромном пространстве, которое находится сбоку от представленных тропинок, но могут находиться и на вашем пути.

Задача - сокрушить врагов и найти абсолютно все в подземелье: разбить каждую вазу, подобрать каждую монетку, убить каждого скелета. Классическая боевая система: клик мышки - удар, кнопки на клавиатуре - активные умения.

К сожалению, есть в геймплейной системе и ложка дегтя. Проходить все это приятно и интересно, когда у вас есть пространство для маневров и для принятия тактических решений. Но есть моменты, когда вас заставляют входить в маленькою комнатку и просто кликать до умопомрачения, а ваш шанс выжить при этом, если герой уровня невысокого, крайне мал. Представьте, что играя в <<Max Payne>>, вам нужно зачистить маленькую комнатушку без укрытий, в которой находится пятьдесят врагов, и Макс заходит в нее без подготовки, не впадая в буллет-тайм, с одним пистолетом. В такие моменты, как на скриншоте ниже, ситуация приблизительно аналогичная. Эти <<островки>>, скорее, раздражают, чем предоставляют челлендж.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338553353

[h1] Звук [/h1]
Саундтрек в игре подобран гармонично, но и тут, увы, есть один плохой момент. Он однообразен и, что наиболее обидно, - не везде он есть. Даже в битве с финальным боссом, эпичной и кровопролитной, на фоне нет никакого музыкального сопровождения. Слышны только звуки автоатаки вашего персонажа. В локациях, где музыка есть, все чудесно. Вы еще сильнее проникнитесь духом темного фэнтези. 

[h1] О раннем доступе [/h1]
Хочу отметить, что студия <<Thing Trunk>> понимает, что и для кого она делает. Вдохновившись классическими ARPG, ребята сделали игру для любителей жанра, за которой можно весело провести пару вечеров и понастольгировать. И отдельно, кстати, стоит отметить отношение студии к своим игрокам. В <<Book of Demons>> есть возможность выбрать размер подземелья, чтобы, например, даже в том случае, когда в запасе всего двадцать минут на развлечения, игрок мог провести время в игре и добиться своей маленькой цели. Даже об отображении реального времени в правом верхнем углу экрана позаботились.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338640577

Разработчики постоянно интересуются, что можно улучшить и добавить. Но самое большое впечатление на меня произвели Google Формы, которые появляются после прохождения основной сюжетной линии. Двадцать вопросов, в ответах на которые ребята из <<Thing Trunk>> просят поделиться впечатлением и показать им дальнейшее направление движения. Я, владелец <<DayZ>>, подобным отношением был впечатлен. Это действительно ранний доступ, который мы заслужили.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338552853

[h1] Рекомендации к приобретению [/h1]
Если брать в учет нынешнее ценообразование в Steam, то, скорее всего, до своих 419 рублей полной цены <<Book of Demons>> чуток не дотягивает. Но в том случае, если же вы большой поклонник инди-проектов и жанра RPG, то рекомендую брать сейчас. В любой другой ситуации - дождитесь первой распродажи и возьмите вдвое дешевле.

Общая оценка - 7 из 10. Рекомендую!

40892498.review:
巨TM无聊的游戏啊..战斗繁琐, 场景单调, 音乐噪音, 探索无趣.

本质是个"点击"类游戏, 随着游戏进程可以获得技能卡片，然后游戏就分成了两种玩法, 一是鼠标点击(游戏中1/3的神器也确实是跟点击有关), 二是用技能砸过去.
但实际玩起来真的是巨TM无聊啊.. 因为我是点击流, 所以我只评价点击流, 对于技能流无任何意义, 谨慎参考.

首先, 无聊的东西太多, BOSS有盾, 需要点好几下才可以点破才能对它们造成攻击, 然后就是当怪物(无论是不是BOSS)放技能时候点击是无效的, 必须得看着他们放技能结束以后才能继续造成伤害, 而技能施放时间一般都要5秒左右, 就得大眼瞪小眼的看着怪物浮空读技能条.
第二点, 打起来太没意思, 非常繁琐的操作.后面图的怪物都是点4下就读满一个条然后怪物放个被动回一部分血且无敌,解决方法是点三下然后往回跑, 等怪物的条每一秒掉一格掉到没以后再回去继续点, 等三格满了再继续等, 然后再继续点, 这是一种, 另一种是套盾, 打破盾打了几下放技能无敌, 等无敌结束又开始套盾打破盾以后没打几下又开始技能无敌循环. 特别无聊
第三点, 怪物设计太没意思了, 到中后期, 几乎所有怪都会自爆, 自爆以后的毒圈碰到人就会让人物中毒, 人物必须过了5秒以后再去点击人物血条,把毒的状态去掉, 几乎所有怪物都会毒圈自爆, 也就是你需要经常的去点血条去毒BUFF, 有意思吗? 而有的怪物冲撞到角色, 屏幕会出现好几个星星去点击, 点完以后人物栏上的卡片会歪掉一部分还需要再去点它们把它们扶正.

特别繁琐对吗? 
还有BOSS战呢
小BOSS有两个阶段, 中BOSS有四个阶段, 最繁琐的BOSS是召唤流, 自己套盾然后召唤出4个血多又套盾的怪物, 必须把4个盾打破然后再杀死召唤出来的小怪再打破BOSS的盾才能对BOSS造成伤害, 没打几下BOSS一个飞空跳走了, 等走过去BOSS开始读条又开始继续召唤小怪. 这刚一个阶段,要重复4个阶段.

你说这个游戏好玩吗? 窝日..特别繁琐的战斗, 我觉得特别JB SB.
还有就是城镇设计, 就几个商人, 然后什么都没有了. 
我下地牢是为了啥? 是为了赚钱. 我赚钱是为了干吗? 下地牢.
简直日了狗
除了地牢以外什么都没有. 地牢完全完全一模一样, 一点新鲜感都没有. 怪物是套盾技能无敌加自爆, 地图是模块化随机拼出来的, 我都不知道我在玩什么了..

40832046.review:
首先，这是一款小众游戏，恐怕不改变游戏模式很难大众化。游戏本体画面精美，音乐没什么感觉，几乎无剧情，就算怪物猎人都比这剧情多。人物几乎没有描述，主角没有立体形象，只有个外貌，4个NPC稍有描写，大恶魔倒是挺萌的。背景是传统的地下城杀恶魔，整体没什么特别奇怪的，也没有深入的思想。总的来说，这个游戏就是ARPG版本的是男人就下100层，不断的刷就行了。

从操作性来说，这个游戏的行动不是很方便不是很舒适，但是攻击比较简单，通过数字键和戍边就可以完成，跟所有ARPG一样。只不过各种怪物很多都有无敌能力，这让人十分崩溃，在小怪多的时候必须不断的破盾，打断技能，这是非常繁琐的。

游戏的界面感觉很好，和游戏风格相同，各种游戏内部功能也很齐全。

然后，本游戏几乎没什么打击感，打击感和游戏中的角色一样，纸片人对战，所以大概感觉也像是撕纸，只有被怪物暴击的时候才有感觉。不过眩晕摸星星的设定不错。人与AI怪物之间的交互性不错，缺点同样在于过多的重复交互游戏和繁杂，不断打断技能和破盾，还有怪物会各种逃窜。一开始非常有趣味，玩到后来会觉得无聊和重复，这也意味着无法获得用户长期好感度。

总之，缺点已经明确，优点则在于卡牌装备系统和地牢中的一些设定和元素比较新颖，希望能够在后面的游戏中加入多人模式，或者改变游戏模式，变得更有趣味性。如果想要增长玩家的游戏总时间，可以试试，比如说增加更多的传说装备，套装，更多技能，而不是通关后无尽的刷层。类似DIABLO，同样是刷，DIABLO的正反馈机制就好得多，这是由于刷到独特的，有用且更好的装备，确确实实的鼓励了玩家，同时也可以多次重复刷BOSS。

40774618.review:
Wer wie ich vor langer Zeit ungesund viel Diablo I gespielt hat und gleichzeitig etwas für Trading Card Games übrig hat, macht mit diesem Spiel nix falsch. Zwar sind einige Spielinhalte fast eins zu eins vom Klassiker entliehen, aber während des Spielens überwiegt für mich doch das Gefühl, ein neuartiges Spiel vor mir zu haben, in das viel Herzblut eingeflossen ist. Im Grunde gibt es wie im Original zwei sich abwechselnde Spielabschnitte: Im Dorf gibt es die aus Diablo 1 bekannten Charaktere, die Heilung und Identifikation (soweit bekannt) sowie Upgrades und den magischen Kessel (neu) übernehmen. Hat man sich hier eingedeckt, geht es in den Dungeon. Hier gilt es erstmal, den Schock zu überwinden, dass man sich "auf Schienen" durch das Verlies bewegt. Seltsame Design-Entscheidung. Vor allem die ersten Level wirken dadurch besonders langweilig. Danach entfaltet das Spiel trotzdem schnell sein Suchtpotenzial, weil die Gegner sehr abwechslungsreich sind und man sich auf die Jagd nach Karten macht, die in diesem Spiel Fähigkeiten, Buffs und Items darstellen. Diese Karten kann man in erweiterbare Slots legen, um sie schnell benutzen zu können bzw., im Falle von Buffs, auszurüsten. Das Spiel enthält sinnvolle Features, die man sich früher in Diablo I gewünscht hätte. Z.B. erhält man jetzt eine Benachrichtigung, wenn man alles an Loot auf einer Ebene eingesammelt hat. Hat man sich am Ende durch alle Ebenen durchgekämpft und Diablos Origami-Vetter besiegt, kann man unendlich oft weiterspielen, um neue Schwierigkeitsgrade und Karten-Upgrades freizuspielen. Es gibt auch viele Achievements, die etwa zur Hälfte leicht zu erhalten sind und zur anderen Hälfte unendlich weit fern für einen Gelegenheitszocker sind. Die Achievements haben sogar ingame eine Bedeutung, wenn auch nur eine kosmetische. Sie halten zumindest nach dem ersten Durchspielen an der Stange.

Hier sind die positiven und negativen Aspekte, die mir beim Spielen ins Auge gefallen sind:

+ Sehr hübscher Grafikstil :)
+ Flüssiges Gameplay mit sinnvollen Skills und Items
+ Sammelfieber beim Finden von neuen Karten
+ Spiel wird regelmäßig geupdatet und hat eine einfache Feedback-Funktion
+ Fairer Schwierigkeitsgrad
+ Alle Gegnerfähigkeiten werden beim ersten Auftreten kurz erläutert
+ Convenience-Features
+ Man kann nicht wie im Original an explodierenden Fässern sterben

+- Es gibt noch keine Quests (ist wohl noch geplant)

- Magischer Kessel macht es sinnlos, sich bei Level-Aufstieg zwischen HP- oder MP-Upgrade zu entscheiden. Man erhält eh beides
- Stellenweise zu einfach, manche Buffs sind overpowered
- Story ist vorhanden, aber belanglos und nicht in Szene gesetzt. Halt wie im Original. Ist vielleicht auch ganz gut so...
- Flexiscope-Feature ist sinnlos. Würde auch ohne funktionieren
- Vergiftungen und Stuns nerven sehr!
- Kein Feedback, wenn man Gegner trifft (keine Schadensanimation)
- Feindlichen Geschossen kann man kaum ausweichen. Und es gibt keine "Abwehren"-Taste/Funktion

Eines sollte man bei diesem Spiel echt im Kopf behalten: Wer sich dieses Spiel kauft und es nicht als das wahrnehmen will, was es ist, nämlich eine einzige Tributzollung an das große Diablo I, der wird sich die ganze Zeit ärgern, dass so viele Dinge 1 zu 1 übernommen wurden: Angefangen bei den Dörflern (von denen der Elder tatsächlich sogar wie Deckard Cain klingt) über die Szenerie und den Gegnern ist wirklich alles von Diablo I abgekupfert. Der eine freut sich vielleicht über die Reminiszenz, der andere mag sich über die freche Selbstbedienung am Klassiker ärgern. Über den Grafikstil lässt sich ähnlich streiten.

40712345.review:
First of all, I'd like to thank developer for allowing to play demo - I still think that it's best way for player to figure out if (s)he will like this game or not. That's why I bought it right after finishing the demo.
Second - this particular demo will lie to you.

I can not recommend this game, and not due to some bug (it works perfectly, and visuals are good) - its core is rotten. Whole campaign gives you great casual 5-6 hours long experience (0 deaths, 100% completion on every level). If it worth its price tag - it's up to you to decide.

Then comes the freeplay. Same randomly generated levels, but with increased difficulty. And here comes the issue - how this difficulty is achieved. In my previous deck-building dame (Slay the Spire) creators made enemies stronger with every Ascension level, simultaneously adding new cards that might help you to build your deck in a new way. And in my opinion it's the right way to make games like this harder.

Book of demons takes oppposite approach. It just ***ks up your deck to make game more difficult, blocking some cards in boss battles and forcing you to keep some cards in your hand. It's particularly obvious with the archer, which can randomly trigger bosses from across half of the map with a stray arrow. If random strikes successfully - you can be left with 10% of your damage output and no options to escape/heal. It didn't happen to me (I survived few close calls), but I can easily picture it happening, especially on dificulties after second.

TL;DR: Deck-building game that doesn't let you to build your deck with the cards you have, choose, and spend fortune to upgrade. Or lets you to build it, but not use.

40709197.review:
What a wonderful fun game! I'm only 3 hours into it--3 hours of solid gaming, by the way, of which I've enjoyed every last minute, but I'm already VERY HAPPY that I bought this! The graphics are delightful, the game is tons of fun--not too easy, not too hard! and I have a steady feeling of accomplishment. I also love the TONS of different monsters, and different types of monsters, in the game, and I'm glad to see that Book of Demons has a sense of humor, as well. 

A couple of things: I do hope that they add more cards! There are over 30 now, and they're fun to play with, but I'd love to see these get added to; hopefully, on a regular basis. Honestly, with a game like this, I really hope that they add more of everything, because constantly discovering NEW STUFF!!! is a lot of the fun! It's not necessary, of course, but it would help keep the game fresh, and that's important, I feel. I also hope that they make something that gives us the random abilities of the original Diablo, where, going in, we never really knew what powers our heroes would end up with. That always made the game more interesting and replayable, because your strategy was never exactly the same. I'm hoping to see more of that, in Book of Demons. It exists now, but it could really be pushed. 

Replayability absolutely ought to be maximized to it's utmost limit, here, and in this kind of game--and yes, I WILL pay for DLC that keeps pushing that limit, on and on.

This is already a really FUN game, that does remind me of the original Diablo--which, to be honest, I actually did like better than the sequel. (It also reminds me of Gauntlet, which was the forefather of Diablo, and it injects some of the slightly-silly fun that Gauntlet had, back into this genre, while enhancing it.) The original had a dark atmosphere, that always kind of kept me on the edge of my seat. Book of Demons does that too, actually! although definitely in a much more lighthearted, less-gloomy kind of way. I kind of like that, even better. It's not the same, but that's good. If I want the same, I can always go back and play Diablo, after all. I don't think I will for a while, though--Book of Demons kind of has me hooked!

40607943.review:
Wish there was a Neutral reaction because I'm very conflicted about this game. It plays like a very watered down Diablo 1 with a cutesy paper artstyle. Generally I was never able to be immersed enough to want to play very often and I kept giving this game a chance and it never blossomed into anything fruitful or meaningful. It's all just a very drab, mouse-clicker experience.

TL;DR RATING: 6/10 - Okay but not great.

=== PROS ===
- THE BEST PART - The Devs are great, very involved with the community, and it's updated often. Even though this game wasn't for me I'm still tempted to back the Studio itself with a "Supporter Pack".
- Artstyle is pretty unique.
- Narration is top notch.
- Ability to choose how much time you have to sit down and play.

=== CONS ===
- The combat is quite dull and uninspired. Your little paper character merely hops when he attacks, the monsters don't flinch or anything from powerful spells, and overall it just feels like you're clicking what's on the screen.
- Movement is restricted to straight lines.
- Mouse / Keyboard is kinda wonky when targeting and moving at the same time.
- Gameplay elements constantly draw your attention away from the action. When you get poisoned for instance, a little icon appears above your healthpool that you click to cure yourself; well you have to manage that while being attacked from all sides. I get that it's probably to make the game difficult but it definitely limited my immersion having to constantly check for effects that I needed to click on away from all the action almost offscreen.
- Leveling up does nothing for you but increase health or mana.
- There's no equipment or loot in the way you would expect from a Diablo-esque game. It's all cards that are basically abilities you would've gotten from leveling up in any other ARPG. Your skills are all gifts of RNG which annoys me to no end.

40568357.review:
This game is pure Diablo Origami art. 

It's a fun twist on the hack & slash genre and it's really one of a kind.  Love the atmosphere and feel of the game.  I just killed that first big boss (looks like the Diablo Butcher) and love it!.  Looking forward to finish my first playthrough with the warrior.

For those that want to know more about the game here goes....
There's no gear in this game, none! You only have skills you get from cards that you will get as drops and must equip in the skill bar. Those are a bit like Path of Exile skill gems except there's with no support gems and they don't level with experience. You simply need to get special cards and gold to upgrade your skill cards.  Even the skills for different types of potions like health and mana are cards you get as drops and equip them to be able to use them.  So you main focus will be buying more card slots to equip more skills and upgrade those cards.  
When you level, you will get points to invest in Health or Mana.  But you can also get extra Health or Mana points from just killing and looting stuff.  Some of these items will end up in a cauldron that the lady npc in the village has.  This will accumulate and you will need to buy from her so she can brew that cauldron.  once she does, it's random but you might get all kinds of stuff like extra permanent health of mana points, gold or other stuff (havent played too much so far so not sure what else it can drop).  Also, the cards can drop Magical and legendary versions of them which can have extra properties on them.

Your character can only walk on this predefined road that you can't move out of like a car road with a single lane but you can only go forward or back so you cannot turn until you hit an intersections and decide where to go from there.  

The different type of monsters will sometimes swarm all around you and block you in so you better always have a skill that will knock them out of your way else you might have more difficulty surviving.

You must at least try this game!

Thing Trunk has a good games on their hands, I wish them the best and please make more games like this.

This is already part of my 2018 favorites list.

40374164.review:
[h1]Book of Annoying Mechanics[/h1]
[i]Book of Demons[/i] strives to modernize the old-school Diablo isometric hack/slash gameplay. It ultimately fails by trying to invent new mechanics that are less fun and more tedious than necessary. I’ll be listening the positives and negatives below.
[h1]The Good[/h1]
[b]Modernized Adventuring: [/b]  you get too choose how long it takes to progress through levels in the dungeon, these range from a few minutes to an hour, letting you enjoy the adventure at your own pace.
[b]Town Without a Portal: [/b]  You can venture to town in-between floors, reducing the necessity for Town-Portal spells, but this also comes with a draw back as there’s no real point to the Town-Portal spell they put in game.
[b]Multi-Stage Bosses: [/b]  Mini-Bosses and regular Bosses are designed to be more like a puzzle than a meat-sack with a billion health, there’s more focus on the mechanics rather than the classic Diablo Hit>Dodge>Hit repetition.
[b]Card Me:[/b] Lots of variety in the different attack/defense/passive/limited-use cards, with each one having additional variants that can be found in the dungeon.
[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[b]Elemental Mechanics: [/b] Quite possibly one of the most annoying features depending on class. Certain monsters have elemental health, meaning you need to counter it with the corresponding elemental spell. Problem is, characters like the Rogue only have Arrow-Spells that have a % chance to inflict elemental damage, so you’re stuck grinding away on some monsters for a very long time.
[b]On-Death Spam: [/b]  Finally grind down that elemental monster? Chances are, another different elemental monster will spawn on it’s death. This isn’t an issue at first, but becomes huge after the second act, where almost every monster spawns a second monster, forcing you to sit there and play whack-a-mole.
[b]Hit-And-Wait: [/b]  Certain monsters ‘rage’ if you hit them too fast, too many times. You have to wait between shots or else the monster regenerates health. None of them are a challenge to fight, it just wastes your time as you sit there slowly plinking away on some +10 health monster for a minute.
[b]Hitboxes: [/b]  For an isometric game, this one is fairly punishing as far as hitboxes go. Play as the rogue, and watch as your arrows phase through monsters as you try and figure out what exactly constitutes as a hitbox. Diablo was much more lenient in this regard.
[b]Why-Upgrade?: [/b]  Each spell/ability/passive card has multiple magical versions of itself. You don’t know what they are, or when you’ll get them, but chances are you probably has a shitty version of whatever card you’re using. It’s extremely expensive upgrading cards through two additional stages, making it feel pointless to upgrade unless you get a Legendary version of a card.
[b]Movement System: [/b]   You move along a preselect path, which isn’t bad, but the game can have a really bad time figuring out which direction you want to head if you’re using the WASD keys, it's 2018 people, stop doing this.
[b]Crippling FPS: [/b]  Got too many enemies on screen? This game will bring your computer to a crawl unless you’re running a 1080. This is surprising given that Diablo2 could have six times the amount of enemies on screen.
[b]Respawning Shields:[/b] Certain monsters have ‘shields’ that require you to be a certain distance in order to break. Fine, this isn’t bad, but combine it with an elemental monster, and the fact that shields respawn without a visible timer, means you’re going to spend a lot of time slowly grinding down some non-threatening monster. 

[h1]Overall:[/h1] I can’t recommend this game because it figuratively takes two steps forward, and then one back for each new mechanic it reinvents to try and be different from it’s older cousins. The mechanics aren’t exactly punishing, but are designed to extend the grind as you sit there and whittle away an enemy’s defenses. I would have liked to see enemies having less elemental health and more damage as the game is never really threatening once you make it out of the first act.

40340689.review:
First time i write a review in years.
TL:DR: This is a incredibly polished MOBILE game, not a PC game. Not worth the price.

I only played one hour and something stroke me immediately: this is a game designed for a future mobile port.
This might no be necessarily a bad thing, but it is in this case for a couple of reasons:

-You are in a dungeon but you are constrained in specific corridors (look at the trailer), your character moves automatically in a direction you choose until you stop. This gives an oversemplicistic feel to the game that just bothers me when i have a mouse i could do tons of quick and precise actions with.

-You attack monsters in sight automatically (you attack at range with a SWORD!). Again, a mechanic that is perfect for mobile since you don't have precise control with the touchscreen, but just feels so lame on a PC hack n slash.

-Since you walk along corridors where there is no space whatsoever for dodging (you can't move on the side, only forward or backward) all the projectiles coming towards you are almost impossible to dodge. Also there are some monsters attacks that are impossible to dodge too. Paired with the fact that recovering health requires gold (you pay gold in town to refill your potions), it means that the game is designed to FORCE you to pay gold (i can see the in game purchase at the horizon...).

Don't get me wrong, the game is really well done for a mobile game, but again i expect something very different for a price of over 12€.

40329884.review:
Well I "finished" Book of Demons last night. That is to say that I killed the Lord of Darkness at the bottom of the dungeon. You can keep going deeper, which I did for a couple of more games to see how the "free play" worked, and it was fun too.

What can I say? The game has charm. I can't explain why it pulled me in so much. Maybe it was the cards (skills) that you acquire and level-up. Maybe it's the cauldron prize system... So what that is, is as you play thru the dungeons, you pick up weird stuff like teeth, ham bones, green juice, etc, and then the lady back at town pitches it all in the cauldron. The longer you go, and the longer you get more ingredients, the better the brew gets. The brew is actually just a bunch of random prizes, from piles of gold, to runes (used to level up your skills), to new skills. If you die, the brew vanishes uncollected and you start over, so you have to decide when you want to cash out. Cashing out means that you spend an increasing amount of gold each time to get the prizes out. Anyhow, it's an interesting mechanic to make you scared of dying even if you aren't playing Hardcore, which I think is pure genius. In diablo, who cares if you die? It doesn't matter. Here, it does.

I like how the game lets you pick your dungeon size, based on how much time you have. When you start the game, you are presented with a half a dozen or so dungeon sizes, and how long they should take to complete, based on your normal speed. So, it's personalized that way.

There are lots of different enemy mechanics, but you learn them pretty quickly, and if you're a seasoned ARPG player, they are little more than speed bumps. They have one mechanic where you can't kill the mini boss until you kill certain minions around him (noted by dotted lines). There are a couple of interesting fights where you fight a boss like that, but his "minions" are actually two other bosses, so the fight stretches fairly long.

One thing they do get right is the feel of combat. It's fast and responsive, just as it should be.

They have limited tile sets and monsters, you can only walk on certain paths, there is no map (woe is me), but they do have a breadcrumb system that shows you where you've been. Your character hops around the map like a board game piece, and the monsters, players and npcs all look like cardboard cut-outs. These are some of the things that I rolled my eyes at in the beginning until the actual game play pulled me in.

At the end of the day, I think it's the cauldron, the card hunt, the card leveling system, the ability to pick your dungeon size, and the ease of play that makes the game alluring. After each run you don't have to disenchant a bunch of crap, repair, throw a bunch of crap in the stash, or anything like that. It's stripped down to the basic fun - kill monsters and level up your cards. The inventory system is clean and easy.


For $13, I'm glad I played it.

40289073.review:
It's not a bad game. Big kudos to the team for doing something unique with the ARPG formula. But personally I don't find myself too interested in their innovations. But I'll get to that in a minute, because my biggest problem with this game is the fact that it starts with an advertisement for their proposed series of seven games, "Return 2 Games", and to even get into the game, you have to click the book resting on one of seven pedestals that will clearly serve as an avenue to try to get you to buy more of their games, should they even exist. I find that grating. In addition, there are share buttons all over the place. I find that even more grating. If I've bought the game, I shouldn't be pestered with advertisements, or pestered to help advertise. It makes it feel like a free to play mobile game.

And it actually continues to feel a bit like a free to play mobile game. They could transform it into a very sleazy one quite easily with the simplified control scheme and need to "recharge" some cards for gold.

So the control scheme. You move along preset paths, by clicking or WASD (though WASD doesn't work terribly well at some intersections, due to the way it gives priority to going certain ways). This simplifies movement. Okay... why? I'm genuinely curious. Because it doesn't remove any challenge, so far as I can see. I considered accessibility, but when, as a child, I had a broken arm multiple times, I still played Diablo 2 one-handed. And you still would need two hands to use all your abilities on the number keys, unless you had a many-buttoned mouse. I genuinely don't get the point of it, unless it's for a mobile port down the line.

And the card system. They basically just replaced... everything, in terms of loot and abilities, with cards. I also don't get why that innovation was needed. It just means you get far less loot (not even counting junk loot), and it has a bit of a different theme.

Also, they removed attributes like strength, dexterity, intelligence, and just have health and mana. I don't find that simplification necessary either, but maybe that at least is because I'm not the target audience. And it does fit with their goal of "accessibility" - even if the on-rails control scheme doesn't, as far as I can tell.

There is one very good mechanic they have: the "Flexiverse." Which is basically the ability to decide how big a level is. That is certainly good for accessibility. It's a neat feature more games should have. Because people have lives. And I respect a game that respects my time for that, at least.

It's interesting, and I didn't hate any of its systems (though I did hate the ads), but I just found them less interesting than what they came from. It seems like a step back. Maybe it'd be an excellent mobile ARPG, if the business model wasn't scummy. I don't get it on PC.
