40278321.review:
The mechanics start very simple in [b][i]Book of Demons[/i][/b] — you’ll find beasties of various makes and models roaming the upper floors, slowly shambling arround with little paper hearts over their heads. As you mouse over them, your character will excitedly whack them until they run out of hearts. You can also click on them for better control of which creature is getting whacked.

Unlike an ARPG, the loot in the game comes in the forms of cards. The simple attack mechanics are augmented with cards that drop from foes and chests, granting additional attacks, elemental effects, armor, and more. 
Mana is used to fuel the cards. With a limited pool, you’ll have to balance, as an example, an expensive suit of armor and a shield that can block 50% of incoming arrows, against a spell that lets you smite foes with a mighty fist. Leveling up allows you to put additional points into your health or mana pool, so some pre-planning is important.

As you dive deeper into the dungeon, foes begin to use special powers and attacks as well. Enemies might have a shield that your auto-attack won’t penetrate, requiring the player to furiously click on the shield until it breaks. Other enemies might explode, poisoning both friends and foes in range. 

Sub-bosses are named creatures you’ll encounter that have special attacks. They may summon buddies that render them invincible until you dispatch all of them. They could also have a shield, explode with poison, freeze you, leap across the screen and stun you, or a combination of those and many more. Add in the fact that they have to be dropped to zero health multiple times before they are dispatched, and are randomly placed in the dungeon, and you have a recipe for replay as well as surprise.

While the game is still Early Access [b][i]Book of Demons[/i][/b] are already off to a great start with a great looking and unique papercraft style. Two thumbs up.

[i]Eairly Access Version 0.90.14769+ 18th December 2017[/i]

40275277.review: This game clearly takes its cue from Diablo 2. So much so, in fact, that players familiar with Diablo will recognize the first boss in Book of Demons. That isn't to say that Book of Demons is a rip-off or unoriginal. The things it does take from other dungeon-delving RPG's are the parts of the formula that work and the things it changes are the things that make this particular title engaging, addictive, and charming. The graphics and animations are VERY well done and given that this appears to be the publisher's first title, it looks incredibly polished and professional. The gameplay is very smooth and gives interesting, meaningful choices without forcing players to suffer through a complex system of number crunching that's really geared towards end game when you know everything that's going on already. With a low barrier to entry, a great HUD that's simple and effective, and many unique twists on an already proven formula, one can only hope (if not assume) that the next titles from Thing Trunk will be ones to look out for!

40272157.review:
If you played and enjoyed the original Diablo, then you should no doubt give this game a shot. The way you move around on a set path is different and may turn some people off, but it actually works very well and you get used to it in no time. It is an action rpg but there isn't much in the way of improving stats, you only choose between health or mana every time you level, however there is a card system in place, you find random cards in the dungeons that you can equip to gain spells, abilities or the use of potions. The game's dungeons are randomly generated, but the neatest part about them is that you can choose the size of the dungeons with a time estimation of how long they take to complete judging from how you play, so if you only have 15 minutes to kill you can play a smaller dungeon, or if you want to play for longer and want more rewards you can choose larger ones. There's also three classes in the game, you start off with the Warrior and eventually unlock the Rouge and Mage. The game's difficulty will seem a little easy at first, but it does pick up and later on can be pretty challenging,
Overall I really recommend the game, it's fun and simple making it great for people new to action rpg's, while also appealing to the crowd who played the original Diablo.

40264406.review:
I don't normally write reviews, I prefer to keep my opinion my own, however since I was asked to I shall.

Book of Demons (BoD) is an ARPG, akin to Diablo, Path of Exile, and other games like it.

However, where these games use striking graphics, BoD uses cardboard cutouts that look straight out of a poor kid's DnD session. The style is somewhat niche, but I find it charming due to how it isn't shoved into the player's face.

The gameplay intrigues me, where games like PoE, Diablo, and Grim Dawn failed to hold my attention, this game held it. In all the previous games one must know how they want their final max level build to turn out at the very start. As such, playing through them and getting screwed around level 20 almost invariably made me displeased. This game does not do such a thing.

I enjoy character customization, but the simplicity of the game's card slot is a breath of fresh air. In addition, another niche feature is the card system. I adore card games above all others - and it was the reason I even gave the game a chance.

It doesn't focus too heavily on it, but still retains a large enough presence that I enjoy the execution of it.

All in all, a fun game that's easily worth the buy.

This is shaping out to be a fantastic game. I don't usually review games, but I'm having such a wonderful experience with Book of Demons, that I felt compelled to write something positive about this superfun game from R2G - a relatively new indie game studio.

The graphics are great, the gameplay is fun, the music and sound is good. Only the RPG elements are slightly underwhelming, but are sufficient. Combat is slightly simplistic, but it's still fun. 40023716.review:
I played the demo and enjoyed it, so I donated for the supporter package. I am running through using the mage now. As you would expect, it is quite a bit different as a mage. It is also much differerent because of the cards that I am getting on this run through which I did not get last time as the warrior. I have yet to try the third class.

My intitial reaction was that the walking speed is a little slow, but when you've played it a bit it matches the somewhat relaxed play style (as I am not using the hardcore mode - it is relaxed!).

Playing in 'expert' or hardcore mode is something I will do next.

The novel way that you interact with the foes you encounter is interesting and fun. As a totally different alternative to the way other games out there play, it seems to work well. For example, if a foe has a shield you have to literally click on the shield they are holding to break it with your attacks. This means you have to concentrate on that and can't do much else about whatever is attacking you. Similarly, to break a boss or mini-boss's special attacks you'll need to click and hold on a marker for that. It sounds somewhat odd, but it works to keep you always busy.

It sounds like it might not work - but it does work.

So, in a nutshell, grab the demo and then buy it! I do not regret donating the supporter package having now had the full game for even a short time. Because of the way the random cards are dealt and the monsters are generated and interact, it has a lot of replayability even at this early stage of development.

It has never crashed on me or had any bugged feature.

p.s. Did I mention that the paper graphics style is really done well?

39721237.review:
Fresh front-of-the-box quotes: 
"This game is a diamond in the rough, and is absolutely worth any Diablo fan's time and money."
"Do you like Diablo? Then play this game now."
"Paper-cuts have never been this fun!"

I rarely ever decide to write reviews for a game, but this game has made me absolutely want to leave one for anyone wondering about the quality of this game. I originally purchased this game a year or two ago when I was on a Diablo kick, and found it irresistably charming, but with only one class at the time and many other features pending it was a work in progress so while I enjoyed it immensely I shelved it for a bit so as to see if the devs would continue to update it, and holy crap have they ever been working hard!

Fast forward two years later, I picked it up again and this game is more feature rich than many currently released games, and this game is still a few months away according to the (very active) developers and their roadmap. Let me explain the current state of the game:
It is absolutely brilliant. All 3 classes have now been released, and all are at a extreme level of polish. The last class--the Rogue--was released at the tail end of last year after the other two had been out a while, the devs ensured it was not released until it was truly good and ready. The game itself is maybe 6 months away from release, but that is because they wish to add in even MORE features and polish it even more. This game is perfectly enjoyable as is, and I recommend anyone who enjoys Diablo type ARPGs to give this a try.

Pros:
+Perfectly captures the Diablo feel without any of the excess trimmings (could be positive or negative depending on your viewpoint, for me it's a positive)
+3 distinct and complete classes (Warrior, Mage, Rogue)
+Amazingly deep and feature rich card system for abilities that is FAR more than I can ever explain here
+Has a Flexiscope which lets you select the size and time length of the dungeon you want to run. Only have 15 minutes? Run a small dungeon and still get your rewards!
+Extreme replayability, all dungeons are randomly generated like ARPG fans enjoy!
+Combat system is just like Diablo, click or hold to attack and number keys or right-click on cards to use spells/abilities
+Can run on just about any computer
+Absolutely charming paper-cut art style
+No in-game transactions or cash shop, at ALL. Everything is earned in game only
+Is the first of (I believe) 7 games to be released by this company, each encapsulating a gaming genre perfectly like this

Cons:
-Is strictly focused on capturing and encapsulating Diablo without the frills that accompanied it, strictly on the ARPG combat and dungeoneering aspect (As I said, can be positive or negative depending on what you want out of it)
-Art style may not be for everyone or some may think it is too 'cartoon-y'
-Movement can feel restricted as your path, while branching, is somewhat set (Hard to explain, easier to see in action. I enjoy it quite a bit now as it helps keep things going but it seems to be the #1 detraction I hear from people)
-No skill trees like Diablo, all abilities are gained from cards you loot  (Note: All cards are earned in game, there is 100% NO cash shop or any possible way to get them besides playing the game, so do not worry about that aspect)
-Is still technically in 'Early Access' though the game is feature-rich enough for release, the developers just want a even higher standard for their product before they will establish the game as 'Released'
-Can be very difficult as the game goes on, throws many enemies at you with very innovative and different mechanics (A positive in my opinion, but some people dislike a nice ramping difficulty and/or multiple enemy mechanics so I left it down here)
-No online play or lobbies like is common in Diablo II and other such games (I don't particularly mind the lack of it as I prefer the single player aspect, and the developers have stated it's not totally off the table in the future if they ever wanted to add it) but I know a lot of ARPG players expect online play to be standard

TLDR for the lazy: If you're here, you are likely a fan of Diablo/ARPGs. If you are, or are on the fence--just buy the game--you will NOT regret it.

39684891.review: Fun and engaging game mechanics. 39684355.review:
The Book of Demons, on its own, is a great little game. The paper art-style and obvious inspirations from Diablo make for a satisfying experience at $20. The developers nail their intent to tap into the nostalgia of older gamers, while at the same time appealing to broader audiences.
 
There’s quite a bit to be happy about here. With 3 playable classes I’d imagine that you could easily get 40-60 hours out of the game if you try and squeeze the most out of it. The item/card system is fairly unique and does a good job of pulling those strings that make me want to complete “one more run”. The fact that you can also determine the average length of time to commit to each run is also implemented in a very cool way. 

On the flip side, Book of Demons itself does have some optimization issues. I’m running a Core i7-4770k system with 16 GB of ram and a 1080 GTX, but get some disappointing frame issues later in the game when moderately larger amounts of mobs are spawning. I also find that the movement, while on rails, “felt” unresponsive though this may just be a factor of the rail system itself. Lastly, in my opinion, there’s just not a ton of depth here for an ARPG. It’s a clear straight shot down the dungeon levels until you hit the end boss. If you’re looking for a vastness and diversity of content like you’ll find in D3, Grim Dawn of POE, you won’t find it here.  

There are more books to come, an implied 7 total, which will be added to this collection bearing the same art-style. I assume each installment will cost the same $20, so we can gather that in the end the full collection will be around $140. No clear time table has been determined for when future offerings will be added. Nor is there any specific indication of what genres will be represented with each release. In looking at the Support pack upgrade at $50, you can discern that it may ultimately be a great deal.

All in all I can recommend Book of Demons to just about anyone. It does what it sets out to do very, very well.

39672831.review: Reminds me of the desolate tombs of Diablo.  The pathing may turn you off at first, but the streamlined approach actually adds a bit of a challenge.  If you enjoy arpg's you'll probably enjoy this.

39672260.review:
It is a masterpiece. Of the thousands of hours I have spent playing ARPG, Book of Demons offer a fresh and fun experience. Its core offerings to me are three.

(1) Replayability. Dungeons are randomly generated. Boss stages are random. The cards or builds that you bring to the higher difficulty or against each boss could also have a random element to it that either work for or against you.

(2) Flexibility on time. I can determine the dungeon size based on the time I have to play this game. Be it as a 10 mins run. Or a 40 mins run. I have total control over it. I will still get the reward in the end. For someone who has a certain real life obligation, this is wonderful.

(3) Catered for "mid-core" players. I.e. appealing for both casual and hard core players. There aren't any complicated mathematic formula behind the scene that I would need to research upon. Everything is intuitive. When I spend time playing and learning the game, I can be a good players. It is less reliance on the hours long gear grinding in the traditional ARPG sense but the ability to counter each mob type around me given the constraints I have. And that would include the positioning of my character that some may find it strange while I find it an absolutely necessity (and genius design really). This design makes the concept of enemy strong tanks in front and powerful but fragile casters behind works. This design also makes enemy summoners really scary at times.

Other than the above three core strengths of the game, I like the artwork of Book of Demons. The voice acting is fantastic. At the time of writing this review, I have played 30+ hours. My warrior is at level 50 now playing nightmare difficulty. I can't wait to see this game coming out of early access. I will definitely give hardcore (or "daredevil") a try because it seems doable.

All the best to Thing Trunk for the remaining books to be published. You have a fan here :)

39668407.review:
Sometimes I play a game and it makes me want to cry. This was one of those. I fear this gem will not get the attention it deserves.

Good story.
Excellent, funny writing.
Fantastic voice acting.
Amazing soundtrack.
Cool graphics.
Tight, responsive gameplay.
A fresh and innovative take on the ARPG genre.
Fun!

I've just completed my first full playthrough, and I can't wait to do more. There's endless replay value with harder difficulties, different classes, everything is randomly generated for a fresh experience each time, and even challenge achievements for truly daring and talented.

If you're on the fence about getting this game, don't be. It's great on every level!

39633656.review:
This game was a dissapointment for me. You movement is restricted to back and forth making it impossible in many cases to manouvre, so the only thing you do is move forward or backwards and spam the attack button. There is almost no gameplay involved except for picking some equipment from the cards that take away your ability to use Mana, which is absolutly fine because you really dont need it as long as you spam that button. Oh but there is a twist.... armored oponents require you to spam a different button before you can continue spamming the attack button... 

Someone compared it to Diablo, but the only thing this game has in comon with Diablo is the viewpoint of the camera.

39619707.review: This game brings me back to the days of old school Diablo without the headaches. The game is more of a stylistic redo of the original Diablo than it is a game that pays homage to it. I'm personally not much into card based RPGs but the system put in place here makes it feel more like they are actual pieces of equipment than they are consumable items that go away after one use. It's fast paced but does require you to actually pay attention to everything around you otherwise you'll get overwhelmed. I've yet to get frustrated with this game as I have with other action RPGs and this is a great way to kill time in between your main game between updates or if you're just waiting for the next big title to come out. Overall this RPG is solid, not overbearing, easy to understand and can hold it's own against many of the other "budget" RPGs on steam and I would dare even say it's better than some of the most popular of titles. I recommend giving this game a chance and let yourself get lost in the story, gameplay and visuals. For what this game tries to do, it does it well and I've yet to come across any glaring issues. The only thing that I would recommend is a faster walk speed in the dungeons but this isn't really a complaint, more of a quality of life suggestion. Try out the game guys and gals, you shouldn't regret it.
